node.statement: (Candidate measure rho is well-defined) Define R(phi) := exp(Psi^{ren}(phi)) / Z where Z := E_mu[exp(Psi^{ren})] and Psi^{ren}(phi) = 4 lambda <psi, :phi^3:> - 6 lambda <psi^2, :phi^2:> + 4 lambda <psi^3, phi> + <(-Delta+m^2)psi, phi> (node 1.5.1). Define the probability measure rho on C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3) by d(rho)/d(mu) = R. By node 1.6.3.3: (a) 0 < Z < infinity, so R is well-defined; (b) E_mu[R] = 1, so rho is a probability measure; (c) R > 0 mu-a.s. (since exp(Psi^{ren}) > 0 and Psi^{ren} is finite mu-a.s.). We will show T_psi*mu = rho.
